headline: 'The Five' debate the significance of the Nunes memo

utterances.sentences: That's fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

And we had a long ride. And you get there, and the people were just so gracious. They said, "Oh, you know, you're the author of this book."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a good thing. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You know what was a fun day? I mean, there were a lot, but I would say that day that I found out, like, I passed the bar exam. utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: And for victims' rights.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You should have probably stopped for another little snack of crackers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly. No, I wanted to fix my tie. If I hadn't fixed my tie -- I'd relieve that day.

utterances.sentences: It's too late now!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, when you go back to relive that day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. When I go back to relive that day, no ties. And I won't listen to Jack, who told me my tie was crooked. That's what -- in the studio -- I was in the studio, and Jack goes, "Your tie is crooked." So I turn around and go out. And then I come in, I get hit in the face with the door. And I've never been the same. All right. Gloria G.: "What is the one food you absolutely refuse -- refuse to eat?" And a little joke there: "Greg Gutfeld, honest not silly answer like unicorn." All right, Kimberly, what do you refuse to eat?

utterances.sentences: Beets.

utterances.sentences: Have you ever had borscht, beet soup?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Obviously not, because I don't like beets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's amazing with sour cream on top.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I don't like beets, and I don't -- I'm not, like, a big fan of onions. I know if they're cooked and they're in there, you kind of --

utterances.sentences: Interesting. Remember that McDonald's would never allow a special order. So it would take hours. They'd have to cook the whole thing. That's another topic. Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. They try to cover the smell of sewage.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Also, as a kid I didn't like broccoli.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.sentences: No, I don't eat fish at all. I try once in a while.

utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.sentences: Yes.

I think this was beautifully done.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're right. That gave me goose bumps.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And they do so much in terms of, you know, law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. God bless.

February 2, 2014, New York City Mayor Bill De Blasio, a.k.a, Lurchface, dropped a groundhog named Charlotte at the Staten Island Zoo's annual Groundhog Day ceremony. Well, all of that came flashing back to me today when Randall Margraves, the 58-year-old father of three gymnasts who had been assaulted by Dr. Larry Nassar stood up in court and brought some major drama after being denied a minute alone with Nassar. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL HARGRAVES, FATHER OF THREE GYMNASTS ASSAULTED BY NASSAR
utterances.sentences: Could you give me one minute?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You know that I can't do that. That's not how I would --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, John Grisham wrote a book called "A Time to Kill." And to my mind, I guess that's what this dad had on his mind. It would have been on my mind.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Indeed. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, we tried to book the therapy peacock and was denied. So I had to settle for Donald Trump Jr., and we talked about -- you guessed it -- the memo.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP JR., SON OF DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: There is a little bit of sweet revenge in it for me and certainly, probably, the family, in the sense that, if they wouldn't have done this, this stuff would be going on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This would be going on at the highest levels of government. They'd be continuing to do it to my father, trying to undermine his actions. Imagine how effective he can be, given the year he's had, without this cloud over his head.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I raked this guy over the coals so hard, he had nowhere to turn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The most hard-hitting interview you're ever going to see. It's a different side of Don Jr. you probably haven't seen before. So tune in, 8 p.m. on Saturday night. And then watch Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.sentences: Yes. And don't forget the Judge in between.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, can't forget that.

utterances.sentences: Not yet. Except I know that I'm going to be having some chicken wings.

utterances.sentences: Yay, Trump. Everybody is getting chicken wing bonuses.

utterances.sentences: I mean bonuses. I mean bonuses, I certainly do. Juan, where are you going to watch the Super Bowl?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Dana. This -- like four-page memo first reported by Fox News makes the case that the secret national security court was kept in the dark by the FBI and Justice Department when they sought and secure a surveillance warrant for Trump campaign aide Carter Page. The memo says the court was never told the former British spy who was paid by Democrats put together the Trump dossier, that's Christopher Steele, had a personal animist towards the presidential nominee. Quote, in September 2016, Christopher Steele admitted the Justice Department official, Bruce Ohr, his feelings against then-candidate Trump was Steele said he, quote, was desperate, that Donald Trump not get elected and was passionate about him not being president. Ohr was recently demoted over his contacts with Steele. And Glen Simpson who's opposition research firm Fusion GPS directed the Trump project. Bank record obtained by the same house committee show Ohr's wife Nellie worked for Fusion GPS and began investigating Trump as early as May 2016. Republican investigators said the court was also never told about the dossier's political roots. Quote, none of the initial FISA application in October 2016, nor any of the renewals disclose or reference the role of the DNC, Clinton campaign, or any party campaign in funding Steele's effort even though the political origins of the Steele's dossier were then known to senior DOJ and FBI officials. According to the memo, deputy FBI director, Andrew McCabe, who was removed earlier this week testified before the committee in December of last year that they would have never gone for a surveillance warrant if it not been for the dossier.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Catherine, one question. So, Speaker Ryan and the White House both said today that they encouraged the Democrats to try to release their version of the memo. Do you have any idea what the timing of that might be?

utterances.speaker: HERRIDGE
utterances.utterance: Well, they've got to go through a number of processes in terms of classification. I think one of the big distinctions with the Republican staff memo is that it was deliberately drafted with the idea that it could be made public quickly, so they eliminated a lot of national security information sources, methods, anything that was sensitive. The Democrat's version is 10 pages long, but it would also be subject to an inter-agency review. So, it could take some days.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Thank you, Catherine, appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: HERRIDGE
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump shared his thought on the memo from the oval office today moments before it was released.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: I think it's terrible. If you want to know the truth, I think it's a disgrace. What's going on in this country, I think it's a disgrace. What's going on -- a lot of people should be ashamed of themselves and much worse than that. Let's see what happens. But a lot of people should be ashamed. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. We'll take it around the table starting with Kimberly, who knows a lot about the FBI process and getting a FISA warrant and all that goes in to it, your thoughts. KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: Yeah. There is a few things that jumped out to me right away that are sort of like the exclamation points, and what I thought was interesting is that they excluded the political origins on the sealed dossier that were known to senior DOJ and FBI officials, but they were left out and excluded from the FISA application. And I feel that that, in of itself, is sort of glaring because it shows the motive and the intention and intent to deceive, some duplicity on their part, which I think is totally inappropriate in terms of what they were supposed to be transparent about and put forward in proper in terms of supporting documentation and what they knew. And if they knew about the political origins of it, that, in of itself, should have cast doubt on the credibility. They purposely withheld that information. So to me, that is a significant glaring factor, and probably like number one on my list.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, another part of it was that the media helped played a role in this in a way. So, apparently, Steele leaked information about the dossier to Yahoo News. Yahoo News writes the article. And then, apparently, the FBI when applying for the warrant said that there was corroboration because it was in Yahoo News, but they did made it explicit that they actually -- Steele used his own information to get into Yahoo News. What do you think of that? JUAN WILLIAMS, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: Well, I don't think much of it. I mean, to me it doesn't matter. Clearly, the FBI cut off contact with Steele once they suspected that he was leaking information. But this thing is so comical to me. I said to Greg in the greenroom, Greg your astir because this is zero. This is comical. I was thinking there's going to be something here, some element here that's really going to cause people to take a second look. Instead, you have a situation where Kimberly is talking about Steele having some political dislike for President Trump. That doesn't speak to the information in the memo. And secondly, guess what, it didn't even prompt the investigation. The investigation had started before with the news that the FBI uncovered George Papadopoulos's connection with Russian agents who are trying to win him over.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And that is included in the memo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And so, I don't understand. And then secondly, don't forget that Carter Page have been under FBI scrutiny since 2013, Dana. So, again, this is not even pertinent. I mean, I don't get it. I'm struck by the number of Republicans, Republicans, who have said today -- I'm thinking of John McCain who said basically that Nunes and the Republicans here are doing Putin's work. John Kasich said it was an attack on American institutions and erodes our democracy. John Thune said we've got to get past this. This is not good. I don't get it. So President Trump said ashamed. He should be ashamed of using Nunes and the congress in this way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, Jesse, I'm assuming you think differently? Juan says he thinks it's comical, but you're not laughing. JESSE WATTERS, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: I'm laughing at Juan's speech. It's a kill shot, Juan knows it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A kill shot. Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the reason Juan can't admit it is because to admit it he would have to admit that he's been wrong for a year. They were caught red handed in a conspiracy that the left accused the Republicans of being involved in. It involved the media. It involved Hillary operatives in foreign countries. It involved the Department of Justice and the FBI under Barack Obama. You say the FBI cut off contact with Steele after they caught him leaking? Then he backdoor through the Justice Department. And the person whose wife was working through Fusion GPS ended up being demoted, Bruce Ohr. You say this didn't prompt the investigation? You know what did prompt the investigation? Strzok, the Trump-hating, corrupt, FBI official, so what's worse? You're also saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excuse me. Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Strzok responded when Papadopoulos was found to being recruited by the Russians. And then, he was subsequently taken off in the investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, he hates Trump. The fix was in. He cooked up the Hillary deal, and then opens up an investigation on Papadopoulos off of some conversation over in London? That's not a big deal, Juan? To me it is. You know what else is really interesting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Someone like you is so desperate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is not desperation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You, guys, we've got to get Greg in here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to say one thing to Kimberly. Juan, if James Comey is signing off on three FISA application warrants and he knows the application was based on a document -- the dossier was paid for by Hillary and was unverified and salacious. Why would we do that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: First of all, it wasn't based -- there's no indication this was the total basis for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, they said if the dossier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: McCabe said it under oath.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, actually, did you not see the thing that Bret Baier said earlier that the Democrats are disputing that, but McCabe didn't say those exact words. So, who knows? Maybe when their memo come out Greg will have more information on that. GREG GUTFELD, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: Well, you know, the thing is -- since this whole thing started, this nerd Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I said that I didn't think -- I don't have a dog in this hunt. I'm not interested in being proven correct that nothing happened here. When somebody says there's nothing to see here, that means there's something to see here because there's always something. It's clear when you look at this that there is something. And when you step back and you see this mosaic of malfeasance, when you see things like the tarmac and you see things like the servers and the text messages and the Comey statement. And then you see the political roots of this dossier and why the political roots of the dossier were covered up. Why would they do that? It stinks of Clinton. This is all about Hillary Clinton. She -- I mean this is to help her get elected. We spent the last year and a half hearing about collusion between Donald Trump and the Russians, and all along the real collusion was committed by the perpetrator of that narrative. So you look at the media, the Democrats and their allies in government those are the people that have been colluding. They were colluding about a narrative and they were colluding before the election. If you think that's not huge, then you're probably a hack.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm a hack then.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm a big hack. Because I remember hearing people -- you know, Fox and in the conservative echo chamber say bigger than Watergate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't think it's going to be much of anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You guys have not raised one thing that would say to this audience, boy, this is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I'll raise it right now, Hillary paid for the surveillance of Donald Trump's campaign. They used false information to spy on Trump. They knew it was false.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What false information?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The dossier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The dossier was false because McCabe said it was false and Comey said it was false.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But Comey said, quote, ready, salacious and unverified.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What difference does it make who pays for it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What difference does it make? OK, Mrs. Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've just quoted the secretary from Benghazi.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just say, what difference does it make who pays for it if the information is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Political B.S.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: FBI gets information from a guy who's like -- seedy character, but it turns out to be good information.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We know it wasn't good information, Dana, because it's never been verified.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not saying the dossier is real. I'm just saying that that is what Juan is saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You see the dossier you get a warrant. It's like trying to buy beer with a library card.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Have you tried that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I ask you one thing, Kimberly, about the process because I am curious about this, and we don't know this from the memo. So, if Carter Page is under a FISA warrant starting in 2013. You have to go to the FISA court every 90 days in order to keep up that warrant. We don't know if there was a lapse in the warrant between 2013 and 2015. We don't know if this is a new warrant about Carter Page, right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So the problem is there a whole chronology issue here as well in terms of when did they get it? Is this new? At what time? And it also goes to the larger issue, as Jesse was saying, of veracity in terms of the content and the facts that are alleged there. So, if you have a question about that, you have to verify it to make sure that it was substantiated and there was some kind of initial proof or evidence to support any of this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I ask you one other thing on this legal point which is -- because I want to give you one more chance to talk since these guys talk a lot. If you're a FISA judge and you're presented information that you think was based on faulty information, like how mad would you be? What are the consequences of that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Furious because somebody could be held in contempt of court. Lying to the court providing false information or false affidavits. I mean, this goes to the integrity of the whole judicial process and saying that in good faith and belief that you have the information that you're relying on is truthful and to be relied on by an officer of the court in order to justify, essentially, a search.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Imagine if you're presenting to the judge. You don't say one of my pieces of evidence is an article from Yahoo News. That's actually what they're saying was one of the pieces. I don't know all of the details here. We'll find out if the Democrats are going to come out with their memo and we'll have more of the full picture. But we're going to talk about this a little-bit more. Memo fallout ahead and a programming note, Devin Nunes is going to join Bret Baier, exclusively, tonight at 6 PM Eastern for a live interview on this document he commissioned. Don't miss that. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Back now with more on the FISA memo fire storm. What kind of fallout will this have on the FBI and on the Department of Justice? Former FBI director James Comey took to twitter today to give his reaction. He writes, quotes, that's it? Dishonest and misleading memo wrecks the house intel committee. Destroyed trust with intelligence community. Damage relationship with the FISA court and inexcusably exposed classified investigation of an American citizen. For what? DOJ and FBI must keep doing their jobs. Jesse, how do you respond to Jim Comey?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Say that was too long.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he needs to take some lessons from Trump on being not as verbose.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Winning in twitter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, winning. I think Comey has -- since he's been fired looked worse and worse and worse from the leaking of the memo to the ridiculous comments on twitter to the book now. If you at his twitter page it's all about the book release, so we know what's he's trying to do there. I want to put out a real fine point on what Kimberly said because I do think she's right. It's the crux of the issue. When they applied for these warrants they knew it was based on false pretenses that were paid for by Hillary Clinton, and they didn't disclose it to the judge. They purposely withheld that Steele hated Trump and was connected to Fusion GPS. I also want to touch on something else. Remember for a year, the Clinton campaign denied they had anything to do with the dossier until, eventually, it came out that they did. And again, they used fake news to get the warrant. You know, they shopped the stories around, and then they tip the Newsweek or it was a Yahoo deal and they give it to the judge. So everything that the left has accused Republicans of when it comes to collusion, when it comes to pushing fake news, they themselves are guilty of.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Kimberly, I just want to go back to the Comey memo for a second. He said it damaged the relationship between the intelligence community and the congress. And the intelligence committee, obviously, requires oversight, people appreciates transparency. But if you're in the congressional committee at this point, you're thinking to yourself, gee, I don't know if the intelligence community is going to share information with us anymore because people will use it for political attacks like this Nunes memo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But you're also thinking, perhaps, we would like to make sure that we could rely on the authenticity, the veracity, the truthfulness of information that is being provided to us that we are reviewing. That it isn't -- we're not being used as pawns in some kind of political chess. And so, that's a problem too because they're taking their reputation, their basing it on the information that they're provided, and if the information is suspect, lacks veracity, is false in terms of what they're offering for that is a huge problem. That's the bigger picture issue beside like -- you know, what you're saying. That's sort of a collateral issue in terms of what the court hear of the problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Dana, the question becomes whether or not it's trustworthy information, right? And does it matter if somebody doesn't like -- if somebody likes Hillary Clinton, doesn't like, but is doing their job. Christopher Steele must Respected former British intelligence agent. And isn't it the case that there was additional material not disclosed in this memo. Obviously, the average FISA warrant is about 40 or 50 pages, the Nunes memo 4 pages. So there's much missing beyond whenever you think about the Michael Steele dossier.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, yes, of course. This is not the full story, which is why I think the White House -- Sarah Sanders out today to put out a statement, was done on camera. In which she said, the White House stands ready to help the Democrats with their interagency process to approve -- the release of their memo as long as it doesn't affect national security. So, we do need to see that. And the question actually becomes, should we see the underlying documents, the source documents? The FISA applications that went in October 2016. But if that's true, then should we also see the FISA applications from 2013? And I don't know if America really need to see all of that. I think the Justice Department need to have the integrity of investigations because if you start doing this -- it will be a slippery slope for other things. I do think that Comey is unnecessarily taunting people. And it's one thing to walk away, to write a book. You'll have your say when you have the chance to write your book. You will also have a chance, probably, to talk to Bob Mueller who might be called up to congress again. And I think taunting on twitter on either side of this, especially if you're under investigation is a really, really bad idea.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you talking about Trump or Comey?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Anybody. The other thing I would say is this, one of the thing that happens in Washington, in particular, or anywhere is that there is -- you want to protected yourself. There's self-preservation here. These are people's careers and livelihood. And I would not be surprised if you see additional news stories and leaks of some sort as a result of this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Anyway. So Greg, one serious question here. Lots of thought.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was getting used to your humorous ones.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Lots of talk today in Washington, is this then a precursor for Trump to fire Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, who approved one of these FISA request?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not into hypothetical questions, and I think that might have been hypothetical. I would like to focus more on Comey's tweet, the fact that his criticism was over the release of the information, not the information itself, and I think that's interesting. Comey claims he was mad that they expose classified information. I think it was more upset that it exposed the mistakes that he made depending on that dossier. And using it today you see people fretting about transparency, who didn't seem to mind when President Obama ended Chelsea Manning's prison sentence. I think that's interesting. This is the most transparent government I've ever seen. I'm learning so much, aren't you? Aren't we all learning a lot?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I feel like there're some holes here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. I think this is way better than 4 years than political science at any college. Donald Trump presidency, you learn more in a year than you would in Harvard.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's like saying about economics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's like the national economic lesson.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think I learned that he doesn't like this investigation and he wants it to stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They love you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He does? Good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A new crackdown on comfort animals on a seat next to you on a plane after a -- get this, peacock fiasco. That's next with Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Traveling by air can give a lot of people anxiety, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Some people bring animals on board with them to provide comfort when they fly. But policies are changing on some big airlines. United bounced a passenger recently who showed up at the airport with a peacock for emotion support. Now the airline is tightening rules to make passenger confirm their animals are trained to behave in public and have vaccinations from a veterinarian. Now, Delta just tighten is policies on comfort pets and American is considering doing so as well. Now, I never particularly thought, Greg, that a peacock would be comforting, but there are those that do. Is there anything that would help you when you travel to relax, any animals?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My comfort animal is wild turkey.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I will have a double.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. Here's the lesson and we know this lesson, every time a new system is invented, there will be an accompanying effort to game it. So, when you get cable, someone will try to steal your cable. When you create a currency, there will be counterfeit currencies. So when something good happens, there're other people that will take advantage. Unfortunately, people who are gaming the system, who are bringing these animals on just to bring them on so they don't have to pay for shipping them or whatever, they're actually hurting the real patients like veterans with PTSD because-- when somebody games the system, it makes you suspicious of everybody else. For example, if somebody is abusing drugs recreationally, then the patients who want to get that drug are also under scrutiny by the doctors. If you happen to actually need opioids, people are going to think you're abusing opioids because it is such a big deal. So this is what happens. Now when you see people with a pet you're going, I don't believe it. Peacock, please.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, what's your problem?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. But there're people with real problems.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Real problems.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not like pretend little problems. OK. So Dana.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's me.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, I think you're doing better, actually.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: As long as you get there like 3 hours ahead of time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have an experience with this on a plane where a woman brought a parrot with her on the plane, and she was sitting in the row ahead of me. It was like a 3-hour flight. And she talked baby talk to this bird the entire flight and it was super annoying. This is before Wi-Fi and stuff so you could, you know, distract yourself.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right. So OK --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Was it a baby bird?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: A follow-up question. So would you ever consider making Jasper a comfort animal?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I would, except for Jasper's so famous, and I would be that person who ruins it for everybody else. Right? I would be -- I don't need an emotional support dog when I go on a flight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you've looked into it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I did not look into it, because I would -- no, because I would end up on the front -- I would end up disgraced and --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "My dog is too famous to be a therapy pet."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: America's comfort dog. Keep up with the themes here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "My dog is too famous. I don't know what to do."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness. Good voice-over. Hey, Jesse, did you find in your, you know, experience with the llamas, was that comforting to you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that was terrifying. And we had a person with an emotional support squirrel on "Watters' World," except the squirrel felt asleep, and he didn't want to wake it up, so that bombed. We tried to book the woman with the bird and she denied me, so I'm a little angry at her. I just want to talk about the memo, actually. I mean, this whole FISA application, they didn't --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Kill shot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, seriously. Can we get back to the memo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, I was much more interested in Bullwinkle flying with Rocket J. Squirrel when he was there. I was fascinated by that. I don't get this, but it seems to me an era of indulgence. I think Greg often talks about people have nothing better to do, so we live in this very highly-entitled, you know, happy, comfortable society; and we make a big deal out of this. Now, I'll tell you from experience, what's interesting is this is protected under the Fair Housing Act. Who knew?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why would that be? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's worthy of a "guess what?" and you didn't even use it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't. I should have used it. I should have used it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One in the bank.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but they want to protect people who actually need assistance animals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, for people who --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Blind people or people with PTSD. There are people that need this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How do you come up with a peacock, though? Like what -- I love a peacock. They're great. They're beautiful, majestic birds. But, like, what makes you think they're emotional --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Show-offs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How do you cuddle up with a peacock?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Peacocks are -- they're a show off. The bird -- the whole thing is about status. It carries that around, to tell its mates that it is so powerful that it can carry this burden of feathers, so you should have sex with me. That's what a peacock is.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. I -- we --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the whole point of the feathers.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Seven point five seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's to say -- it's like if you carried a piano around.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you carried a piano around, people -- women would go, "Oh, wow, he's so strong." That's the whole point of the feathers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like when guys wear their collar up with their T- shirt?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who would that be?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think -- like you. I think that was evidence of the neurological condition when you got hit in the head, and we're going to chalk it up to that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Stay with us. We wish you would. As "The Five" gears up for Super Bowl Sunday. It's coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Forty-eight hours away from the Super Bowl. My Eagles are in it. That's me at the NFC championship game when they defeated the Vikings. Why is Greg laughing? I can feel it. They're going to win. More than 100 million people are expected to watch --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- but according to a new poll, 16 percent of NFL fans said they won't even tune in this year. No data on why, but 46 percent said they disapproved of this year's national anthem protests. Meanwhile, some people think the Monday after the Super Bowl should be declared a national holiday so everybody can sleep in and recover from their hangovers. A majority of H.R. managers are even in agreement with that. Gutfeld, I know you probably do this segment every year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you agree with the -- ?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can't -- if a hangover keeps you from work --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Then I'd never --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- you don't deserve to drink. I don't want to -- or work. I don't want to tell you how many times I've sat at this table wondering where the hell I am. You know what? My favorite thing about the Super Bowl are the ads, of course.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't wait for the My Pillow ad.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't wait for the Cars -- what are the Cars for Kids going to do?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's going to be incredible. And of course, William Devane, who is my spirit animal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think Devane could afford the cost of the Super Bowl ad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he can. Haven't you seen his farm?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That tree?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He took you to the far?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Look at my tree." Have you ever seen the commercials?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That wasn't a tree. Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- tell me your thoughts on the keys to the game?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you have to score more points than the other side.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very good. Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know more than you think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's all I get.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not sure about that. So do you think they should be -- you should take off on Monday, a national holiday?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So you want to work five days a week instead of four? That's why you're Dana Perino. You're just such a goody two shoes. You want to show up every day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ask Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you want to go to work on Monday?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Why wouldn't I?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Am I the only one that wants the day off?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We don't like to take days off.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, we like to work.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- and to work. Why would --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why is that? There's something about having perfect attendance that makes you feel really good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And you like to brag about it. It's like bragging, "I only sleep four hours a night, and I've never missed -- had a sick day." Yes. Anyway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who's done that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The president? Juan, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, it's interesting to me is what they counter program on other channels. And it looks to me that that 16 percent may be undersold, because there's always, like, Hallmark Channel movies. And I think lots of women, if they can watch, they watch. Now I think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dean Cain Sunday.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I think there are lots of guys who aren't particularly big into the football thing, and they want to see -- so I think ESPN does bowling championships. And you're thinking, who's going to watch that? Turns out it does pretty well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And there's FOX News.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Has their own --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're on the memo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's our Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: DVR the Super Bowl. Watch breaking news about the memo. Let's just go around quickly. Who's going to win? Patriots or Eagles?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Patriots.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: God. Kimberly!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You know why? Because if you do an analysis of quarterbacks, and like, Brady always comes from behind. He's great on third down conversions. Even if it's, like third and twenty-fifth, the guy's --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm just telling you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, Vegas says the Patriots, but my heart says the Eagles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go. Juan and I actually agree on something.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Way to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's my "One More Thing." So I'll have to hold it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't care. I honestly have not thought a single thing about the Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, what are you going to eat?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What am I going to eat? I don't know. I'll probably be sleeping. I'll probably be sleeping. I'm sleeping the whole weekend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, don't fall sleep now. "Facebook Friday," up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Why are you -- ?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (singing)
utterances.utterance: Alka Seltzer. Plop-plop, fizz-fizz, oh, what a relief it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was a relief.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Eww.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Facebook Friday," America. Let's begin. A great question, from Mary Ellen Z.: "In honor of Groundhog Day what one day in your life would you like to relive?" We'll go this way. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The one that comes to mind is when Peter and I lived in England, and we went to Scotland to pick up Henry, our first puppy. That was a good day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I knew it was going to be a dog. Jesse, is yours dog-oriented?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. I would like to relive Sunday, this coming Sunday, when the Eagles win the Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're -- you're going to -- you're reliving a day in the future, which is kind of interesting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That just blew your mind.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'd say it's optimistic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, it's like -- I mean, I can do things like remember when I had a book coming out. It got great reviews. And the publisher agreed to let my mother drive with me out to where the book was coming off the press.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And it was an amazing experience. And so now I was thinking about it. You know, it was such a great time. Because I was in the car with my mom, which is unusual. And we had a long ride. And you get there, and the people were just so gracious. They said, "Oh, you know, you're the author of this book."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What a moment in life.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a good thing. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You know what was a fun day? I mean, there were a lot, but I would say that day that I found out, like, I passed the bar exam. It was fun, because I thought of all the exciting things I could do with my legal career and become a prosecutor. And I wanted to, like, fight for, you know--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Justice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And for victims' rights.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I would go back to last week, Monday at 5 to 5 p.m. And instead of walking towards the door at 4:55, I would wait approximately 10 seconds. And then I would not have this raging headache for the last 10 days that is making my head want to explode.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You should have probably stopped for another little snack of crackers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. No, I wanted to fix my tie. If I hadn't fixed my tie -- I'd relieve that day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Stop wearing ties.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's too late now!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, when you go back to relive that day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. When I go back to relive that day, no ties. And I won't listen to Jack, who told me my tie was crooked. That's what -- in the studio -- I was in the studio, and Jack goes, "Your tie is crooked." So I turn around and go out. And then I come in, I get hit in the face with the door. And I've never been the same.

utterances.speaker: All right. Gloria G.
utterances.utterance: "What is the one food you absolutely refuse -- refuse to eat?" And a little joke there: "Greg Gutfeld, honest not silly answer like unicorn." All right, Kimberly, what do you refuse to eat?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know people are going to object to this. But I'm really not a big fan of beets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Beets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like beets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No Super Beets?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do they advertise?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Have you ever had borscht, beet soup?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Obviously not, because I don't like beets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's amazing with sour cream on top.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't like beets, and I don't -- I'm not, like, a big fan of onions. I know if they're cooked and they're in there, you kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She picks them off of her hamburger from McDonald's.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know. Right? See?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Interesting. Remember that McDonald's would never allow a special order. So it would take hours. They'd have to cook the whole thing. That's another topic. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't like cauliflower at all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And also, but I had a recent change, because I used to not like Brussels sprouts. But now people present them, and they're, like, stir- fried and crispy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. They try to cover the smell of sewage.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: With bacon.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Also, as a kid I didn't like broccoli.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think George -- is it George W. Bush?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: H.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: George H.W., yes. He liked them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he caused a whole scene.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He did. That's what I'm recalling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, Jesse. Anything you refuse to eat? I've seen you eat everything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's not a lot that I won't eat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I tried to impress a date one time at a nice restaurant and ordered sweet breads. And then I was told in the middle of what I was eating what they were, which are glands.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I had a panic attack and had to excuse myself and go to the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Did you throw up?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Almost.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Glands.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Raw fish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Will never do it, never.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Sushi?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I don't eat fish at all. I try once in a while.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'll bring that into the greenroom on Monday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't eat -- I do not eat any seafood whatsoever. It comes from the earth's toilet. That's what the ocean is, the earth's toilet!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You swim in the ocean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not when I can. I don't mind a good lake. Swimming pool. But the ocean, come on. It's dirty in there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I once ate a puffin in Iceland. A puffin, you know, those adorable birds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Isn't that an endangered species?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It tastes like shoelaces. Yes, OK. This is good. From Linda N. I'll go with you, Juan. "What book has -- "

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, not -- don't ask Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: " -- left a lasting impression on your life, not just your career?" You can say any of my books, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, Greg's books really made an impression. I would guess, you know, "Invisible Man."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not the science fiction one, the Ellison one?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Ralph Ellison one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But then there are things like "The Chosen," Chaim Potok's book, which I think is about a kid growing up in Brooklyn. That made a big impression on me.

utterances.speaker: And you know, this is silly, but it's true
utterances.utterance: Huck Finn, Tom Sawyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I loved those books.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. What about you, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Besides the "Killing" series, Greg? I'm going to go with my old standby, "The Hobbit." You know, can't go wrong with "The Hobbit." JRR Tolkien. Great book. Great series.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana. Book?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would say "A Wrinkle in Time."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who did that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Madeleine L'Engle. Lengel? Lengal?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. Remember "The Little House on the Prairie"?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I liked those books, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Ingalls Wilder books.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Those were good. And "Charlotte's Web" was great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to guess Nancy Drew for you, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's my favorite?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Had a lasting impression.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Nancy Drew I definitely loved. But also "Little House on the Prairie," the whole series.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was going to -- I liked Pamela Sue Martin.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't know who that is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Nancy Drew show that was on after "The Hardy Boys." People at home are going, "I remember."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's a -- you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A millennial.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The best book? I would have to say "Envy" by Helmut Schoek. Look it up. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Thank you so much. You'll like this thing. A new class of K-9 bomb-sniffing cops graduated today from the NCA Police Department in New York City. Thirteen teams completed an intense 12-week explosive training program, and the dogs were trained to investigate suspicious packages, and each dog got their own shield for their reward. In a touching tribute, each of the dog are named after a fallen police officer, firefighter or soldier to honor those that served us and fallen in the line of duty. I think this was beautifully done.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're right. That gave me goose bumps.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And they do so much in terms of, you know, law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Keeping us safe.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. God bless.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Best thing you can find is dogs. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Saturday, February 3, that's tomorrow, 10 p.m. Boy, do we have a show for you. We've got Johnny Joey Jones. You've got comedian David Angelo. We've got Kat Timpf, Tyrus. We are going to blow the roof off that night. Keep watching. All right. Time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's On This Day in History.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's On This Day in History." All right. February 2, 2014, New York City Mayor Bill De Blasio, a.k.a, Lurchface, dropped a groundhog named Charlotte at the Staten Island Zoo's annual Groundhog Day ceremony. The poor creature died several days later after being dropped. Now, the zoo says the drop was maybe unrelated to the death, but he's not attending this year's ceremony, the mayor, because he's a murderer! He's a murderer! He's a murderer!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are we allowed to say that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's kind of a little weird.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to lighten it up a little bit. Last night on "Jeopardy," I happened to be seeing it, it was clear the contestants did not know anything about the Super Bowl or football. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Football, 400. ALEX TREBEK, "JEOPARDY" HOST: I can tell you guys are big football fans. Tom Landry perfected the shotgun formation with this team.

utterances.speaker: TREBEK
utterances.utterance: The Dallas Cowboys. Do you think we should go to commercial? Let's look at the $1,000 clue just for the fun of it. If you guys ring in and get this one, I will die!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, they did not get any of them. And I told Jesse that I would give you my prediction. So I think this is your first time being a part of Dana's mascot theory. I base my theory on who's going to win --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- based on their mascots. But I think you might like this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have determined, based on the mascot, that the Philadelphia Eagles will beat the New England Patriots. The Eagles were on the brink of extinction until a couple of years ago, making them the Comeback Kid.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Just like Philadelphia. And the eagles are master huntsmen and a potent symbol of power, and that's why they represent countless nations like America the beautiful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Take it to the bank.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't Patriots have guns?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, don't ruin it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So when I was a young reporter in D.C. covering the courts, I remember seeing a defendant get in a bloody fight with court officers. Well, all of that came flashing back to me today when Randall Margraves, the 58-year-old father of three gymnasts who had been assaulted by Dr. Larry Nassar stood up in court and brought some major drama after being denied a minute alone with Nassar. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL HARGRAVES, FATHER OF THREE GYMNASTS ASSAULTED BY NASSAR
utterances.utterance: Could you give me one minute?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: You know that I can't do that. That's not how I would --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, John Grisham wrote a book called "A Time to Kill." And to my mind, I guess that's what this dad had on his mind. It would have been on my mind.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Indeed. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, we tried to book the therapy peacock and was denied. So I had to settle for Donald Trump Jr., and we talked about -- you guessed it -- the memo.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP JR., SON OF DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: There is a little bit of sweet revenge in it for me and certainly, probably, the family, in the sense that, if they wouldn't have done this, this stuff would be going on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: This would be going on at the highest levels of government. They'd be continuing to do it to my father, trying to undermine his actions. Imagine how effective he can be, given the year he's had, without this cloud over his head.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I raked this guy over the coals so hard, he had nowhere to turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Another hard-hitting interview.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The most hard-hitting interview you're ever going to see. It's a different side of Don Jr. you probably haven't seen before. So tune in, 8 p.m. on Saturday night. And then watch Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And don't forget the Judge in between.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, can't forget that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, what do you -- do you have Super Bowl plans?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not yet. Except I know that I'm going to be having some chicken wings.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Excellent. Remember, usually, there's a chicken wing shortage. There's not one this year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yay, Trump. Everybody is getting chicken wing bonuses.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Chicken wing bonuses?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right before we started, Best Buy has announced they're giving everyone bonuses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Crumbs you mean, Dana. You mean crumbs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean bonuses. I mean bonuses, I certainly do. Juan, where are you going to watch the Super Bowl?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's my son-in-law's birthday and the Super Bowl, so we're having a party at our house.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So can we bet that you're going to have pictures of the family on Monday for "One More Thing"?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I hadn't thought of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks a lot, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Have a great weekend, everyone. "Special Report" is up next. Bret has a special interview tonight. Over to you.
